data.tldr: I have worked on various types of projects for personal clients, companies, and government organizations throughout my development journey. Recents are under NDA, I will be happy if yours is not, but good ones are often lies here. I often work as a part-time developer (20h/W) and take on additional contractual projects that require a few hours of maintenance each week. The rest of the time, I enjoy learning new things and contributing on different platforms. I also enjoy bug hunting and refactoring Flutter projects.  You will find me efficient in Flutter application development. I prioritize working on ethical projects that align with my values and avoid anything that conflicts with my principles.

items.name: Flutter & Application Development
data: My expertise shines in the Flutter framework, as I spend most of my time working with it.
GoRouter is my go-to choice for routing.
I prefer ThemeExtension over a static theme class.
I like code generation but prefer writing small cases manually (e.g., JSON, ThemeExtension).
I love animations. Yes, I have created many cool animations in Flutter, but for heavy character level computation, I use Rive.

items.name: Backend Development
data: For backend solutions, I work with Firebase, Supabase, and Serverpod. If you have a backend developer, any backend solution is fine—whether it's REST, GraphQL, or WebSocket.
I have been using Golang with PostgreSQL as a database since last year, but I am still in the learning phase for backend development.
I use FVM Flutter SDK and Docker for backend development consistency.

items.name: State Management
data: As for state management, I prefer Bloc. Riverpod, Provider, or built-in solutions are fine. Please don’t invite me to a project using GetX.
For SDK or concern separation, I use InheritedWidget or just Stream—yes, Stream works well as a state management solution for mid-level projects.

items.name: Dependencies & Architecture
data: I prefer adding fewer dependencies and only those that are well known (not by popularity/likes but understood, performance, and well-maintained).

For large projects, I prefer a mono-repo pattern with Melos. However, this is usually unnecessary for most applications if the project is well-planned. Otherwise, I prefer a simple architecture based on dependencies, separating domain, presentation, and infrastructure (especially for mid-to-large applications).

items.name: Version Control & CI/CD
data: Git for version, task, issue control, and code reviews.
I prefer CI/CD tools like Git, Bristi-CLI, Code-Magic for building or deployment. Otherwise, I use a makefile to make life easier.

I like writing only unit tests but often face issues with rapid changes that break things. Usually, organizations/clients don't provide enough time/requirements to write unit/widget tests often for rapid development and feature changes.

items.name: Documentation
data: For documentation generation, I prefer using dartdoc. This has become my coding style. Notion doesn't feel like home yet.

items.name: Development Environment
data: I use Windows as my primary workstation and Debian on my laptop. VS Code is my primary editor, and nowadays, I try NeoVim outside my workspace.

items.name: Communication
data: For casual communication, Telegram is okay. For team collaboration, Slack feels better. Microsoft Teams? A very confusing experience.
For task management, GitHub Issues/Projects, Jira, and Trello work fine, but I’m still not comfortable using Notion for task tracking. Don't tell me you still use Excel sheets for task management.

items.name: Philosophy & Learning
data: My philosophy on writing code is to make it understandable by humans—including non-programmers.
I prefer tasks to be clearly prioritized based on business impact and like to break large tasks into smaller, manageable pieces.

I’m always eager to learn new technologies and basic computing (80's), often dedicating personal time to explore emerging trends. But I am not interested in learning low performant tech despite being popular, PHP or Python for backend; I am interested in Rust and have a future goal in it.
I love programming over drag-and-drop development.
I prefer an effective coding style and material design (Currently investing time in UX as well).

principles.title: My Work Philosophy: Values and Limitations

data: Projects that involve unethical hacking, illegal activities, or deceptive business models (e.g., pyramid schemes, get-rich-quick apps)
Projects that violate privacy, security, or ethical guidelines
Projects that violate Google Play or App Store policies
E-commerce or services related to haram products (e.g., bars, alcoholic drinks, tattoos, adult content, etc.)
Teams or organizations where I will face pronoun issues (e.g., they/them)
Any type of gambling or dating applications
Crypto or NFT projects
Toxic company culture or excessive workplace politics
Clients looking for low-budget developers
Companies that demand unrealistic deadlines with unfair compensation
Micromanaging clients who don’t trust developers
Projects that lack clear vision, proper documentation, or realistic expectations
Projects with a poorly defined or constantly changing scope
Unpaid trial work or 'test tasks' before hiring
Equity-only payment models with no guaranteed compensation
Clients who expect endless revisions without extra pay
Non-technical clients who refuse to listen to expert advice
Excessive NDA or contract restrictions limiting future work (while I’m open to reasonable NDAs for sensitive projects)
Spam, fake engagement, or deceptive marketing projects
Not interested in full-time work exceeding 35 hours per week
Timely payment and clear communication are essential to me. If I have to chase payments or remind clients/org about the work I've already done, it goes against my professional values.

data.tldr: Open for a postgraduate program in Computer Science, Software Engineering, AI, Data Science, or Machine Learning—where I'll interact more with computers than humans 😀 while benefiting humankind. I hold a Bachelor's in Computer Science and Engineering (GPA: 3.67/4) and work as a Software Developer (Flutter).

principles.title: Philosophy of Studying Abroad for Postgraduate

items.description: Do I think pursuing a Master's is the right path in life? Based on my experience and knowledge, my answer would be no. However, exposure to a foreign culture and education might change my perspective. As a software developer, I have collaborated with professionals from 8–10 countries, building global connections. While knowledge is widely accessible, pursuing a Master’s in my home country didn’t interest me, as I found it inefficient for my growth.

items.name: Perhaps I might gain
data: Global career opportunities and networking
Exposure to advanced research and technology
Collaboration with international experts and diverse cultures
Improved adaptability, communication, and leadership skills
Opportunities for innovation, entrepreneurship, and problem-solving
A fresh perspective on global challenges and new experiences

items.name: And the Cost
data: As Ludwig Wittgenstein said, 'The limits of my language mean the limits of my world.' Perhaps studying abroad will enrich my perspective and culture, rather than feeling like Kafka's prison.
Leaving behind my beloved workstation, which I have built over five years.
Family? Not really an issue. My physical presence is not required, and as the eldest, I have responsibilities to maintain. It’s more of my parents’ wish, which I am choosing to follow.
My job commitments—I'm handling two foreign projects, one for over a year. Without a powerful laptop like my PC, working might not be feasible, and I have no plans to bring my old laptop.
Financially, I can work for 1-2 months and live comfortably for the rest of the year in my home country. That won’t be as easy abroad.
Cultural differences can be challenging.

items.description: Knowledge without implementation is a waste to me. Simply spending my time studying isn't enough. The reason I have chosen to study is that it gives me the time and resources to understand the new culture where I might stay long-term. I enjoy programming and building things that align with my principles.

items.name: Preferable programs
items.description: Postgraduate programs in computer and software-related fields, such as Software Development, Artificial Intelligence, or Computer Science.

items.name: Project collaboration
items.description: My expertise lies in Flutter (Android, iOS, web, and desktop applications), and I can work with backend solutions. I learning Go (Golang) for backend development but am also willing to invest time in learning Rust.
data: Leading projects
Building production-level applications for organizations
Contributing to open-source projects
Developing scalable and maintainable software solutions
Collaborating with teams on UI/UX improvements
Exploring AI and machine learning integration in applications

items.name: Good Culture
items.description: I value a culture that promotes inclusivity, learning, and innovation. Whether in academia or the workplace, I seek an environment that supports collaboration, ethical practices, and respect for diverse perspectives. I also appreciate societies that encourage knowledge-sharing, work-life balance, and opportunities for professional and personal growth.
data: Inclusive and diverse environment
Support for international students and professionals
Opportunities for learning, mentorship, and collaboration
Ethical leadership and responsible innovation
Work-life balance and overall well-being
A strong sense of community and shared growth

items.name: Meaningless Opportunities Abroad
items.description: I’ve been working as a remote developer for companies across different countries for the past few years. I’m not just looking for any place to go. I prefer connections with government or recognized organizations and always check if an opportunity aligns with my preferences (as mentioned in the 'Looking For' section).

items.name: Title-Driven Leadership & Empty Recognition
items.description: I’ve worked under professors who care more about boosting their profiles with photos and project names than actually supporting the project. They often skip important details to save money and don’t fully understand the project requirements. The toughest part was working with non-technical people who think they know better than professionals. I’m not interested in working with such groups.

items.name: Cannot Contribute to My Skills
items.description: I’m looking for opportunities that allow me to grow and enhance my skills. If an environment doesn’t offer the chance to learn, improve, or build on my existing knowledge, it’s not a good fit for me.
